My Development Environment

28 Jun 2012

This is less a blog post and more a readme for a future version of myself to set up my development environment on a new machine. Eventually my goal is to create a chef cookbook, similar to 37signals cookbooks, that would automate some of this. For now, a readme will have to suffice.

This guide is intended for the setup of an OSX machine. Parts should still be relevant for linux/unix users. As for Windows…why would you do that to yourself?

All of the software listed in this guide is free.

Xcode

The first thing you are going to do is install Xcode. Pretty much everything you are going to try to install requires Xcode’s compiler. Xcode usually takes about a billion years to download and install so go grab some food and let the waiting begin.

Once the download is finished, start Xcode and open preferences (_cmd + ,_). Navigate to the downloads tab and install command line tools.

If you are a vim user, check out Xvim. It’s a good way to get some core vim functionality in Xcode.

Alternatives

If you want to stay away from installing Xcode, there are a few alternatives.

Command Line Tools Only

For Lion and Mountian Lion users, apple now offers just the command line tools package without Xcode. You can download it from the Apple Developer Site.

OSX GCC Installer

This is a project maintained by Kenneth Reitz of Heroku. It gives you everything you need without Xcode. Check it out on github.

Homebrew

It’s the OSX package manager. Check out the homebrew on github for in more information.

We are going to install:

  • git
  • hub (note: git + hub = github)
  • MacVim
  • wget
  • Zsh
  • rbenv
  • ruby-build

Install homebrew via the documentation then brew install what you need:

$ brew install git hub macvim wget zsh rbenv ruby-build

rbenv

rbenv manages your Ruby versions. ruby-build is a plugin for rbenv that allows your to run rbenv install and build ruby with rbenv. Check out the documentation for more details.

$ echo 'export PATH="$HOME/.rbenv/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
$ echo 'eval "$(rbenv init -)"' >> ~/.zshrc
$ rbenv install 1.9.3-p327
$ rbenv global 1.9.3-p327

Homesick

Homesick is a nifty little gem for managing your dotfiles. My dotfiles are at cknadler/dotfiles on github.

gem install homesick
homesick clone cknadler/dotfiles

def textile

end

oh-my-zsh

Oh-my-zsh is like a wardrobe and a toolbox for your terminal. Follow the installation documentaiton and once you have it installed, run homesick symlink.

$ homesick symlink cknadler/dotfiles

When asked if you want to overwrite, say yes to everything.

iTerm2 & Solarized

iTerm2 is awesome, but dont take my word for it. Here are 17 reasons you should switch from terminal.app.

So you have iTerm2 and it’s great. There are all these new features and it’s so much better than your old terminal. After a while though…it starts to get old… You slowly realize the honeymoon is over and you are trapped with with that awful default colorscheme. Enter Solarized. I pretty much use Solarized everywhere and with good reason. Solarized and iTerm2 go together like tech startups and beer.

Download or git clone Solarized on github and find the iTerm2 folder. There is installation documentation on github (and in the folder). Once you finish installing it, restart your terminal and BAM, all is right with the world.

So, I know exactly what you’re thinking. Solarized is the best colorscheme my eyeballs have ever had the pleasure of viewing, I just wish I could get all of that beauty in Xcode. Sadly, Xcode support hasn’t quite hit the main solarized repo at the time of writing, although chances are it will soon. There is a fork, brianmichel/solarized, with Xcode support and it works like a charm. Follow the installation-documentation and you should be good to go.

Thats it, my whole environment. If I something doesn’t make sense or you have any questions ping me on twitter or send me an email.
